skill.name: skill-management
skill.description: Create, update, test, and manage Agent Skills. Use when creating new skills, debugging existing ones, or organizing skill libraries. Based on official Claude Code documentation.
skill.summary: Create, update, test, and manage Agent Skills. Use when creating new skills, debugging existing ones...
skill.author: Doyajin174

security_audit.summary: This is a pure prompt-based documentation skill containing only markdown guidance. No executable code, no network calls, no filesystem access, and no external command execution. The content provides official Claude Code documentation for skill management.

content.value_statement: Managing Claude Agent Skills without proper guidance leads to disorganized workflows and duplicated efforts. This official guide provides step-by-step instructions for creating, organizing, and sharing skills across personal, project, and team environments.
actual_capabilities: Create new skills with proper directory structure and frontmatter format
Organize skills by scope (personal, project, or plugin)
Configure allowed tools for security and scope control
Share skills with team members via Git workflows
Follow best practices for skill documentation
limitations: Does not execute code or modify files directly
Requires manual application of demonstrated commands
Does not provide skill templates or code generation
Limited to Claude Code ecosystem documentation

use_cases.title: Personal Skill Library
use_cases.description: Build a personal collection of skills for recurring workflows and experiments.

use_cases.title: Team Skill Standardization
use_cases.description: Create and share skills across team members with consistent practices.

use_cases.title: Project-Scoped Skills
use_cases.description: Define skills specific to a project repository for context-aware assistance.

prompt_templates.title: Create New Skill
prompt_templates.scenario: When you need a new skill
prompt_templates.prompt: Create a new personal skill called my-workflow-helper in ~/.claude/skills/ for managing recurring development tasks. Include proper frontmatter with name, description, and allowed-tools.

prompt_templates.title: Add Tool Restrictions
prompt_templates.prompt: Create a read-only skill that can only use Read, Grep, and Glob tools for safe file analysis workflows.

prompt_templates.title: Setup Team Skills
prompt_templates.prompt: Set up a project-scoped skill in .claude/skills/ for code review workflows. Include Git commands to commit and push the new skill.

prompt_templates.title: Organize Skill Library
prompt_templates.prompt: Review my existing skills in ~/.claude/skills/ and organize them into categories. Suggest how to structure skills following the single responsibility principle.

output_examples.input: Create a new skill called git-commit-helper that generates commit messages from git diffs
output: Structure follows single-file format with proper frontmatter
allowed-tools configured for Read, Glob, and Bash
Best practice: Single responsibility principle applied (commit message generation only)

best_practices: Follow the single responsibility principle - one skill for one specific task
Write clear descriptions that include trigger keywords and usage context
Keep SKILL.md under 500 lines by separating detailed content to REFERENCE.md
anti_patterns: Creating catch-all skills with multiple unrelated responsibilities
Using vague descriptions without trigger keywords or usage context
Exceeding 500 lines in SKILL.md without extracting content to REFERENCE.md

faq.question: What is the difference between personal and project skills?
faq.answer: Personal skills live in ~/.claude/skills/ and stay on your machine. Project skills live in .claude/skills/ and can be shared via Git.

faq.question: How many tools can I specify in allowed-tools?
faq.answer: You can specify any combination of available tools. Fewer tools means tighter security and clearer skill scope.

faq.question: Can I use this skill with other AI assistants?
faq.answer: This skill is optimized for Claude Code but applies generally to Agent Skills systems following similar conventions.

faq.question: Does this skill modify my existing files?
faq.answer: No. This skill provides guidance only. You must manually apply any commands or changes to your system.

faq.question: Why is my skill not being triggered?
faq.answer: Check that your description contains trigger keywords, the filename is SKILL.md (correct case), and YAML frontmatter is valid.

faq.question: How does this compare to writing custom prompts?
faq.answer: Skills provide structured, reusable workflows with tool access. Custom prompts are simpler but lack persistence and tool integration.
